chapter.title: Building and Managing Profiles with YaST
chapter.para: YaST provides a basic way to build profiles and manage AppArmorÂ® profiles. It provides two interfaces: a graphical one and a text-based one. The text-based interface consumes less resources and bandwidth, making it a better choice for remote administration, or for times when a local graphical environment is inconvenient. Although the interfaces have differing appearances, they offer the same functionality in similar ways. Another alternative is to use AppArmor commands, which can control AppArmor from a terminal window or through remote connections. The command line tools are described in .

Start YaST from the main menu and enter your root password when prompted for it. Alternatively, start YaST by opening a terminal window, logging in as root, and entering yast2 for the graphical mode or yast for the text-based mode.
In the Security and Users section, there is an AppArmor Configuration icon. Click it to launch the AppArmor YaST module.

sect1.title: Manually Adding a Profile
sect1.para: AppArmor enables you to create an AppArmor profile by manually adding entries into the profile. Select the application for which to create a profile, then add entries.

step.para: Start YaST, select AppArmor Configuration, and click Manually Add Profile in the main window.
Browse your system to find the application for which to create a profile.
When you find the application, select it and click Open. A basic, empty profile appears in the AppArmor Profile Dialog window.
In AppArmor Profile Dialog, add, edit, or delete AppArmor profile entries by clicking the corresponding buttons and referring to , , or .
When finished, click Done.

sect1.title: Editing Profiles

tip.para: Although YaST offers basic manipulation for AppArmor profiles, such as creating or editing, the most straightforward way to edit an AppArmor profile is to open a console as root, and use a text editor (such as vi) to open and edit it:
The vi editor also includes nice syntax (error) highlighting and syntax error highlighting, which visually warns you when the syntax of the edited AppArmor profile is wrong.

sect1.para: AppArmor enables you to edit AppArmor profiles manually by adding, editing, or deleting entries. To edit a profile, proceed as follows:

step.para: Start YaST, select AppArmor Configuration, and click Manage Existing Profiles in the main window.
From the list of profiled applications, select the profile to edit.
Click Edit. The AppArmor Profile Dialog window displays the profile.
In the AppArmor Profile Dialog window, add, edit, or delete AppArmor profile entries by clicking the corresponding buttons and referring to , , or .
When you are finished, click Done.
In the pop-up that appears, click Yes to confirm your changes to the profile and reload the AppArmor profile set.

tip.title: Syntax Checking in AppArmor
tip.para: AppArmor contains a syntax check that notifies you of any syntax errors in profiles you are trying to process with the YaST AppArmor tools. If an error occurs, edit the profile manually as root and reload the profile set with systemctl reload apparmor.service.

sect2.title: Adding an Entry
sect2.para: The Add Entry button in the AppArmor Profile Window shows a list of types of entries you can add to the AppArmor profile.
From the list, select one of the following:

listitem.para: In the pop-up window, specify the absolute path of a file, including the type of access permitted. When finished, click OK.
You can use globbing if necessary. For globbing information, refer to . For file access permission information, refer to .
In the pop-up window, specify the absolute path of a directory, including the type of access permitted. You can use globbing if necessary. When finished, click OK.
For globbing information, refer to . For file access permission information, refer to .
In the pop-up window, select the appropriate network family and the socket type. For more information, refer to .

In the pop-up window, select the appropriate capabilities. These are statements that enable each of the 32 POSIX.1e capabilities. Refer to
for more information about capabilities. When finished making your selections, click OK.
In the pop-up window, browse to the files to use as includes. Includes are directives that pull in components of other AppArmor profiles to simplify profiles. For more information, refer to .
In the pop-up window, specify the name of the subprofile (hat) to add to your current profile and click Create Hat. For more information, refer to .

sect2.title: Editing an Entry
sect2.para: When you select Edit Entry, a pop-up window opens. From here, edit the selected entry.
In the pop-up window, edit the entry you need to modify. You can use globbing if necessary. When finished, click OK.
For globbing information, refer to . For access permission information, refer to .

sect2.title: Deleting an Entry
sect2.para: To delete an entry in a given profile, select Delete Entry. AppArmor removes the selected profile entry.

sect1.title: Deleting a Profile
sect1.para: AppArmor enables you to delete an AppArmor profile manually. Simply select the application for which to delete a profile then delete it as follows:

step.para: Start YaST, select AppArmor Configuration, and click Manage Existing Profiles in the main window.
Select the profile to delete.
Click Delete.
In the pop-up that opens, click Yes to delete the profile and reload the AppArmor profile set.

sect1.title: Managing AppArmor
sect1.para: You can change the status of AppArmor by enabling or disabling it. Enabling AppArmor protects your system from potential program exploitation. Disabling AppArmor, even if your profiles have been set up, removes protection from your system. To change the status of AppArmor, start YaST, select AppArmor Configuration, and click Settings in the main window.
To change the status of AppArmor, continue as described in . To change the mode of individual profiles, continue as described in .

sect2.title: Changing AppArmor Status
sect2.para: When you change the status of AppArmor, set it to enabled or disabled. When AppArmor is enabled, it is installed, running, and enforcing the AppArmor security policies.

step.para: Start YaST, select AppArmor Configuration, and click Settings in the main window.
Enable AppArmor by checking Enable AppArmor or disable AppArmor by deselecting it.
Click Done in the AppArmor Configuration window.

tip.para: You always need to restart running programs to apply the profiles to them.

sect2.title: Changing the Mode of Individual Profiles
sect2.para: AppArmor can apply profiles in two different modes. In complain mode, violations of AppArmor profile rules, such as the profiled program accessing files not permitted by the profile, are detected. The violations are permitted, but also logged. This mode is convenient for developing profiles and is used by the AppArmor tools for generating profiles. Loading a profile in enforce mode enforces the policy defined in the profile, and reports policy violation attempts to rsyslogd (or auditd or journalctl, depending on system configuration).

The Profile Mode Configuration dialog allows you to view and edit the mode of currently loaded AppArmor profiles. This feature is useful for determining the status of your system during profile development. During the course of systemic profiling (see ), you can use this tool to adjust and monitor the scope of the profiles for which you are learning behavior.
To edit an application's profile mode, proceed as follows:

step.para: Start YaST, select AppArmor Configuration, and click Settings in the main window.
In the Configure Profile Modes section, select Configure.
Select the profile for which to change the mode.
Select Toggle Mode to set this profile to complain mode or to enforce mode.
Apply your settings and leave YaST with Done.

sect2.para: To change the mode of all profiles, use Set All to Enforce or Set All to Complain.

tip.title: Listing the Profiles Available
tip.para: By default, only active profiles are listed (any profile that has a matching application installed on your system). To set up a profile before installing the respective application, click Show All Profiles and select the profile to configure from the list that appears.
